source.e8e78527:
model = Sequential()
# Conv Layer
model.add(Conv2D(32, kernel_size=(5, 5), strides=(1, 1),
                 activation='relu',
                 input_shape=input_shape))
# Pooling Layer
model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2, 2), strides=(2, 2)))
# Conv Layer
model.add(Conv2D(64, (5, 5), activation='relu'))
# Pooling Layer
model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2, 2)))
# Remove geometric awareness / prep for ordinary Dense layers
model.add(Flatten())
# Dense layer
model.add(Dense(1000, activation='relu'))
# Softmax output  (array of num_classes values, whose values sum to 1 => can be thought of as probabilities)
model.add(Dense(num_classes, activation='softmax'))
source.3b247f42: As contrasted with a Dense Layer, a Conv Layer has a small collection of weights which is used multiple times and on nodes which are geometrically close
